title: Is A Training Needs Analysis Really Worth It? 3 Reasons To Conduct A TNA

author.name: Hanna Liszniansky
author.bio: Hanna Liszniansky is the Marketing Manager at Roundtable Learning. Before joining the team, she worked for a recruiting firm specializing in reviving the Rust Belt's trades workforce, where she partnered with clients to build hiring pathways and workforce development programs.

excerpt: Your team is under performing. Safety incidents are climbing. Customer satisfaction scores are dropping. The knee-jerk reaction? "We need more training."

content.introduction:
Your team is under performing. Safety incidents are climbing. Customer satisfaction scores are dropping. The knee-jerk reaction? "We need more training."

But here's the problem: Without understanding why performance is lagging, you're throwing money at symptoms instead of solving the actual problem. A training needs analysis cuts through the guesswork and reveals whether training will actually move the needle—or if you need to look elsewhere.

sections.heading: What Is Training Needs Analysis?
sections.content:
A training needs analysis (TNA) is a systematic process that identifies gaps between your employees' current knowledge, skills, and abilities (KSAs) and what they need to achieve organizational goals.

Think of it as a diagnostic tool. Just like a doctor doesn't prescribe medication before running tests, you shouldn't launch a training program without understanding the root cause of performance issues.
list: Organizational level: Company-wide skill deficits affecting strategic goals
Department or team level: Group-specific challenges impacting collaboration or output
Individual level: Single employees struggling with specific tasks or responsibilities

sections.heading: Why Is Training Needs Analysis Important? 3 Key Reasons
sections.content: When KPIs fall short, it's tempting to assume your workforce needs training. But what if the problem isn't employee knowledge at all? What if it's outdated equipment, broken processes, or poor resource allocation?

subsections.subheading: 1. Identifies Employee Knowledge and Performance Gaps
subsections.content: The training needs analysis importance starts with structure. It provides a clear-eyed view of the distance between current performance and required performance.

subsections.subheading: 2. Helps Organizations Efficiently Build a Targeted Training Plan
subsections.content: Generic training wastes time and money. A training needs analysis ensures your L&D efforts hit the bullseye instead of the wall.

subsections.subheading: 3. Provides Insight into New Training Opportunities
subsections.content: Understanding what is training needs analysis means going beyond 'what's broken?' to 'how do we fix it?'

sections.heading: How to Conduct a Training Needs Analysis

steps.step: Generate a Working Hypothesis and Problem Statement
steps.description: Start with awareness. When did you first notice the performance issue? Gather one or two key stakeholders and draft a 100-200 word problem statement.

steps.step: Assess How the Performance Gap Affects Business Objectives
steps.description: Connect the dots between your organization's stated objectives and the task or operation causing problems.
Performance gaps typically fall into three categories: Organizational, Team, or Individual.

steps.step: Refine Your Hypothesis and Create a Manageable Overview
steps.description: Narrow your original problem statement into something conceptually and practically actionable.
Gather both qualitative and quantitative data about your identified chunks.

steps.step: Prioritize and Recommend Targeted Training Programs
steps.description: Combine three elements: data findings, practical judgment, and business objectives.

steps.step: Document the Process and Hand Off
steps.description: Even if a formal report isn't required, document your process for future reference.

caseStudy.title: Training Needs Analysis Example: Oil and Gas Case Study
caseStudy.problem: An oil and gas company faced a surge in safety incidents on their drilling rigs.
caseStudy.solution: Instead of rushing into training, the L&D team conducted a thorough training needs analysis and discovered the real issues were lack of resources and outdated PPE, combined with procedural skill gaps in new hires.
caseStudy.results: Reduced safety incidents, significant time and resource savings, and direct alignment with operational goals through VR-based training.

content.conclusion: A well-executed training needs analysis does more than identify gaps. It clarifies whether training is the right solution, isolates specific development areas, and guides you toward interventions that deliver measurable business impact.

author.name: Hanna Liszniansky
author.bio: Hanna Liszniansky is the Marketing Manager at Roundtable Learning. Before joining the team, she worked for a recruiting firm specializing in reviving the Rust Belt's trades workforce, where she partnered with clients to build hiring pathways and workforce development programs.

excerpt: Learn the essential 4 steps to conduct an effective training needs analysis and improve your organization's learning outcomes.

content.introduction: A structured approach to training needs analysis ensures your training programs deliver real results.

sections.heading: Step 1 — Define the Problem and Success Criteria
sections.content: Write a concise problem statement and agree on how success will be measured (e.g., fewer incidents, shorter onboarding, higher quality scores). Align with business goals, not just training outputs.

sections.heading: Step 2 — Collect Data
sections.content: Gather qualitative and quantitative inputs: interviews, observations, SOP reviews, performance data, LMS reports, error logs, and customer feedback. Look for patterns and constraints (tools, process, environment).

sections.heading: Step 3 — Diagnose Root Causes
sections.content: Sort findings into skill/knowledge gaps vs. non-training issues (tools, process, incentives). Use a simple fishbone or 5 Whys to validate why the gap exists and who is affected.

sections.heading: Step 4 — Recommend Targeted Interventions
sections.content: Map each root cause to the most efficient solution: job aids or microlearning for recall; simulation/VR for practice; process or tooling changes for non-training problems. Prioritize by impact vs. effort and define success metrics, owners, and timeline.

content.conclusion: By following these 4 steps, you'll create training programs that truly address your organization's needs.

excerpt: Extended Reality (XR) encompasses AR, VR, and MR technologies. Learn everything about XR and its applications in corporate training.

content.introduction: Extended Reality is reshaping how we think about training and development in the modern workplace.

sections.heading: What is XR?
sections.content: XR is an umbrella term covering Virtual Reality, Augmented Reality, and Mixed Reality technologies.

sections.heading: VR, AR, and MR — What’s the Difference?
sections.content: Virtual Reality (VR) fully immerses learners in a simulated environment for hands-on practice without real-world risk. Augmented Reality (AR) overlays digital guidance onto the real world using phones or head‑mounted devices to support on‑the‑job performance. Mixed Reality (MR) anchors 3D content into physical space so learners can interact with both digital objects and their surroundings with realistic occlusion and spatial understanding.

sections.heading: Where XR Fits in Corporate Training
sections.content: XR excels when practice, spatial understanding, or real‑time guidance matters: equipment operation and maintenance, safety walk‑throughs, warehouse and logistics scenarios, soft‑skills roleplays, and complex assembly. XR reduces incidents, accelerates time‑to‑competency, and increases engagement compared to slide‑based learning alone.

sections.heading: Choosing the Right Modality
sections.content: Use VR for repeatable practice and decision‑making in simulated environments; use AR for job aids, remote expert support, and step‑by‑step guidance at the workstation; select MR when precise spatial placement and interaction with physical tools are required. A brief needs analysis ensures the modality maps to the performance goal.

sections.heading: Deployment and Infrastructure
sections.content: Modern XR programs rely on device management and an experience‑management platform (XRS) to handle user access, version control, analytics, and content updates across locations. Standalone headsets and mobile devices simplify scaling while keeping IT overhead predictable.

sections.heading: Measuring Results
sections.content: Track completion, accuracy, scenario outcomes, and time‑on‑task from the XRS, then tie those metrics to business KPIs such as incident reduction, first‑time‑right rates, throughput, and retention. Start with a pilot, benchmark current performance, and compare post‑rollout results.

content.conclusion: XR technologies offer powerful tools for creating engaging, effective training experiences.

content.introduction: Virtual reality (VR) is transforming corporate training by offering immersive experiences that engage employees like never before. Organizations face a crucial choice: custom VR training or off-the-shelf solutions—each with unique benefits and challenges.

sections.heading: Custom VR Training vs. Off-the-Shelf Solutions: Overview
sections.content: Understanding the fundamental differences between custom and off-the-shelf VR training is essential for making an informed decision.

subsections.subheading: What Is Custom VR Training Content?
subsections.content: Custom VR training content is specifically designed and developed to address your organization's unique needs, industry scenarios, and business objectives. This approach involves a comprehensive development process that includes needs analysis, instructional design, 3D modeling, programming, and testing. Custom solutions incorporate company-specific workflows, brand identity, and real-world challenges that employees actually face. The development timeline typically ranges from several weeks to months, depending on complexity, but the result is training content that aligns precisely with your strategic goals and can evolve alongside your business.

subsections.subheading: What Is Off-The-Shelf VR Training Content?
subsections.content: Off-the-shelf VR training content consists of pre-built, ready-to-use training modules designed for general applications across various industries. These solutions are developed by VR training providers to address common skill gaps and standard training needs such as safety protocols, soft skills development, or compliance training. The development process is already complete, meaning organizations can deploy these solutions immediately with minimal setup. While they offer less customization, off-the-shelf options provide a cost-effective and quick entry point into VR training, making them ideal for organizations new to virtual reality learning or those with limited budgets.

sections.heading: Choosing Between Custom and Off-the-Shelf VR Training Solutions
sections.content:
The decision between custom and off-the-shelf VR training depends on several factors unique to your organization. Custom solutions excel when you need training that reflects specific processes, proprietary equipment, or unique safety scenarios that generic content cannot replicate. They offer the flexibility to integrate advanced analytics, adapt to emerging technologies, and incorporate your company culture and branding throughout the learning experience.

Off-the-shelf solutions, however, provide immediate deployment and lower upfront costs, making them attractive for organizations seeking quick wins or testing VR training effectiveness before committing to larger investments. They work well for standardized training topics that don't require industry-specific customization.

To help you evaluate both options, here's a detailed comparison of key features:

sections.heading: Do Your Learners Need Custom Or Off-The-Shelf Training Content?
sections.content:
Selecting the right VR training approach requires a clear understanding of your organizational priorities, learner needs, and long-term training objectives. The most effective decision considers not just immediate requirements but also how your training program will evolve alongside your business.

Custom VR training is the better choice when your organization faces unique training challenges that off-the-shelf content cannot address. This includes industries with specialized equipment, proprietary processes, or specific compliance requirements that demand precise scenario replication. Custom solutions also make sense when you're committed to long-term VR training integration, need detailed analytics that align with specific business KPIs, or require content that seamlessly integrates with existing systems. Organizations that prioritize employee engagement through branded, culturally aligned experiences will also benefit from custom development.

Conversely, off-the-shelf solutions work well when you're exploring VR training for the first time, need to address standard skill gaps quickly, have budget constraints, or require training on universal topics like soft skills, basic safety, or compliance that don't vary significantly across industries.

Contact us to discuss how custom VR training can drive measurable business outcomes and transform your organizational learning culture.

content.conclusion: The choice between custom and off-the-shelf VR training ultimately depends on your organization's specific needs, budget, timeline, and long-term training strategy. Custom solutions offer unmatched relevance and ROI for organizations with unique training requirements, while off-the-shelf options provide quick, cost-effective solutions for standardized training needs. Consider conducting a training needs analysis to determine which approach—or combination of both—will best serve your learners and business objectives.

excerpt: Stop separating training from work. That's the core problem with most corporate learning programs – they pull employees away from their actual jobs to learn skills they'll need to apply later, somewhere else, under different conditions.

content.introduction:
Stop separating training from work. That's the core problem with most corporate learning programs – they pull employees away from their actual jobs to learn skills they'll need to apply later, somewhere else, under different conditions. This disconnect costs organizations millions in lost productivity and creates the frustrating gap between knowing and doing.

Phygital training eliminates this problem entirely. By merging physical work environments with digital learning technologies, it delivers instruction exactly where and when employees need it most – during actual work tasks. This isn't just another training buzzword; it's a fundamental shift that's delivering measurable results for forward-thinking organizations.

sections.heading: Phygital Meaning
sections.content:
Phygital combines "physical" and "digital" to describe learning experiences that happen in real work environments enhanced by technology. Instead of taking workers away from their jobs to sit in classrooms or complete online modules, phygital training brings instruction directly to the workplace using augmented reality (AR), virtual reality (VR), and mixed reality tools.

The key difference is context. Traditional training asks employees to imagine how they'll apply new knowledge later. Phygital training eliminates imagination from the equation – workers learn by doing, with digital guidance layered onto their actual tasks and equipment. This direct connection between learning and application accelerates skill development while maintaining productivity.

When a technician receives step-by-step AR instructions overlaid on the actual machine they're repairing, that's phygital. When warehouse operators practice with VR simulations of their exact facility layout before receiving real-time guidance through AR, that's phygital. The technology serves the work, not the other way around.

sections.heading: Phygital in Corporate Training
sections.content:
Corporate training has a retention problem. Research shows that employees forget 50% of new information within one hour and 90% within a week when using traditional methods. This isn't a motivation issue – it's a methodology problem.

Phygital training addresses this fundamental flaw by eliminating the gap between learning and application. Unlike e-learning platforms that remove workers from their environment or classroom sessions that require scheduling around operational needs, phygital solutions embed learning directly into daily workflows.

The difference is immediate and measurable. Traditional training requires employees to:
list: Stop working to attend training
Learn concepts in artificial environments
Return to work and attempt to apply new knowledge
Struggle with the inevitable disconnect between training scenarios and real conditions
sections.additionalContent: Phygital training happens where work actually occurs, using the same equipment, processes, and conditions employees encounter every day. This contextual approach eliminates knowledge transfer delays and reduces the cognitive load of translating abstract concepts into practical actions.

sections.heading: The 3 Core Elements of Phygital
sections.content: Effective phygital training isn't just about adding technology to existing processes. It requires three essential components working together to create seamless learning experiences that enhance rather than interrupt productivity.

subsections.subheading: Contextual Learning
subsections.content:
Learning sticks when it happens in context. Phygital training embeds instruction directly within actual work environments, using real equipment and authentic conditions. This isn't simulation – it's enhanced reality that provides guidance during genuine work tasks.

Consider maintenance training where AR overlays appear directly on machinery components. Workers see exactly which parts need attention, with step-by-step instructions appearing precisely where they need to work. Digital callouts identify potential hazards, proper tool selection, and quality checkpoints without requiring workers to look away from their task.

This contextual approach delivers immediate skill transfer and dramatically reduces learning time. When training occurs in the actual work environment, employees don't waste time and mental energy translating theoretical knowledge into practical application. Skills transfer immediately because they're developed in the exact context where they'll be used.

subsections.subheading: Technology Integration
subsections.content:
The best phygital solutions feel invisible. Technology should enhance workflow, not complicate it. Effective integration means workers can access training resources, reference materials, and expert guidance without breaking concentration or switching between multiple systems.

Smart phygital platforms adapt to individual work patterns and skill levels. They provide just enough information at just the right time, avoiding cognitive overload while ensuring workers have the support they need. The technology becomes a natural extension of the work process rather than an additional burden.

This seamless integration is crucial for adoption. Workers quickly abandon tools that feel clunky or interrupt their flow. Successful phygital solutions enhance productivity from day one, making them indispensable rather than optional.

subsections.subheading: Real-Time Support
subsections.content:
The most powerful learning happens during actual problem-solving. Phygital training provides instant access to procedures, troubleshooting guides, and expert knowledge exactly when workers encounter challenges or unfamiliar situations.

Mixed reality platforms can connect field workers with remote experts who see exactly what the worker sees and provide real-time guidance. This immediate support prevents errors, reduces downtime, and accelerates skill development. Workers build confidence by successfully handling complex situations with expert backing.

Real-time support creates a continuous improvement culture without sacrificing productivity. Employees refine skills and learn advanced techniques during regular work activities, eliminating the need for separate training time that pulls them away from productive tasks.

sections.heading: Phygital in Practice: Real World Examples
sections.content: The proof is in the performance data. Organizations across industries are implementing phygital training solutions and measuring significant improvements in safety, efficiency, and skill development. Here are three examples that demonstrate the practical impact of this approach.

subsections.subheading: Manufacturing and Industrial Training
subsections.content:
A global logistics company transformed forklift operator training using integrated VR and AR technologies. Operators first complete VR simulations that precisely replicate their actual warehouse layout, including real product locations, traffic patterns, and common obstacles. After mastering basic skills virtually, they receive AR guidance in the real warehouse that overlays safety information, optimal routes, and load specifications directly onto their field of vision.

Results speak louder than theory: 40% reduction in training time, 60% fewer workplace incidents, and measurably increased operator confidence. The benefits of VR in warehousing extend far beyond basic training, creating comprehensive skill development programs that address multiple operational challenges.

The seamless transition from virtual practice to real-world application eliminates the traditional learning curve. Operators arrive at full productivity faster and maintain higher safety standards because their training directly mirrors their work environment.

subsections.subheading: Safety and Compliance Training
subsections.content:
A major energy company revolutionized safety training by combining virtual hazard exposure with real-world protocol practice. VR safety training allows workers to experience dangerous scenarios safely, learning to recognize warning signs and practice emergency procedures without risk. This virtual experience connects directly to AR-guided safety inspections and compliance checks in actual work areas.

The impact is measurable and significant: 75% improvement in safety protocol retention and 50% reduction in compliance violations. Workers who experience realistic emergency scenarios in VR respond more effectively to actual incidents because they've already practiced appropriate responses in high-stress conditions.

This approach addresses the fundamental challenge of safety training – you can't safely expose workers to the dangerous situations they need to learn about. Phygital solutions solve this problem by providing realistic exposure in controlled virtual environments, then reinforcing learning with guided real-world practice.

subsections.subheading: Technical Skills Development
subsections.content:
A manufacturing firm tackled complex equipment maintenance training using integrated virtual and augmented reality. Technicians practice diagnostic procedures and repair techniques on virtual equipment that perfectly mirrors real machinery, then receive AR-assisted guidance during actual maintenance tasks on live equipment.

The business impact is substantial: 30% reduction in equipment downtime, 45% decrease in training costs, and significantly improved first-time fix rates. Technicians can practice extensively on expensive or sensitive equipment without risk of damage or production interruption, building expertise before touching critical machinery.

This approach eliminates the traditional trade-off between comprehensive training and operational continuity. Workers develop advanced skills without disrupting production schedules or risking equipment damage during the learning process.

sections.heading: Why Phygital Training Matters
sections.content:
The numbers don't lie. Contextual learning can improve skill retention by up to 90% compared to traditional classroom instruction. This dramatic improvement happens because the brain forms stronger neural pathways when information is learned and applied simultaneously in the same environment.

This enhanced retention translates directly into business value. Faster skill transfer means employees reach full productivity sooner, reducing the time investment required for competency development. Training costs drop significantly when you eliminate instructor travel, dedicated training facilities, and time away from productive work.

Employee engagement increases when training feels immediately relevant and useful. Workers appreciate learning approaches that respect their time and provide practical value, leading to higher participation rates and better outcomes. This engagement creates a positive feedback loop that strengthens the entire learning culture.

The scalability advantage is equally important. Phygital solutions provide consistent, high-quality training across multiple locations without proportional increases in training staff or resources. Organizations can maintain training standards while expanding operations or entering new markets.

sections.heading: The Future of Phygital Training
sections.content:
Smart organizations are implementing phygital solutions strategically, starting with high-impact areas where precision and safety are critical. These early applications typically show the clearest return on investment and build organizational confidence for broader implementation.

Extended reality training applications continue expanding across business functions, from technical skills to leadership development. The technology is becoming more accessible while employee expectations for relevant, engaging training continue rising.

Companies can begin their phygital journey with targeted pilot programs that integrate AR/VR technologies into existing training environments. Virtual reality training solutions provide an excellent entry point for organizations ready to explore immersive learning approaches. Understanding what virtual reality training encompasses helps organizations make informed implementation decisions.

The competitive advantage belongs to organizations that act decisively. As phygital approaches become mainstream, early adopters will have refined their systems and built institutional expertise while competitors struggle with outdated training methods.

The question isn't whether phygital training will transform workplace learning – it's whether your organization will lead this transformation or struggle to catch up. Start by identifying training areas where the gap between theory and practice causes the biggest problems. Those gaps represent your biggest opportunities for improvement through phygital solutions.

content.conclusion: Phygital training represents the future of workplace learning by seamlessly blending physical work environments with digital learning technologies. Organizations that embrace this approach gain measurable advantages in productivity, safety, and employee engagement while reducing training costs and time-to-competency. The technology is proven, accessible, and delivering results across industries. The only question is when your organization will make the shift.

author.name: Hanna Liszniansky
author.bio: Hanna Liszniansky is the Marketing Manager at Roundtable Learning. Her experience gave her firsthand insight into how inadequate training fuels turnover and limits opportunity—especially in trades and skilled professions. Today, she's focused on championing learning-first approaches that grow and retain the next generation of workers.

excerpt: When we talk about XR trends, we're covering the whole field of virtual reality, augmented reality and their hybrid called mixed reality. And there's a lot to cover. Businesses and organizations are seeing more and more how XR technology can deliver results on numerous operations or initiatives.

content.introduction: When we talk about XR trends, we're covering the whole field of virtual reality, augmented reality and their hybrid called mixed reality. And there's a lot to cover. Businesses and organizations are seeing more and more how XR technology can deliver results on numerous operations or initiatives. This article will show the latest innovations in XR training.

sections.heading: The Current and the Future State of the XR Training Industry
sections.content:
Numerous figures circulate the internet about the market size of XR. Getting the right information is hard to do. Some figures say hundreds of billions but a report from market research firm Technavio has the global market for XR technology topping $1 trillion in the next decade. And while businesses are always looking at revenue, this article is more about training and the actual technology to help with that.

Extended reality trends for workplace needs and corporate training are looking more towards hardware. They're also looking at the practical features of that hardware. They also want proof of the practical, results-based potential for XR training itself. But XR devices are something we can hold in our hands, or on our hands or wear on our faces.

Extended reality trends 2025 and into the future show a lot of promise for corporate training in immersive environments. This article explores where XR is heading.

subsections.subheading: XR Safety Training
subsections.content:
The capacity to train in lifelike environments without the actual major physical hazards is a universal benefit of these XR trends (and XR in general).

The trades are increasingly more desirable career options within the marketplace. The need for safety is going to increase. Additionally, the continuously accelerating capabilities of XR make soft skills and communication-based workplace needs more suitable to immersive environments. But in any job, safety is a given and extended reality trends are part of it.

Take Roundtable Learning's full-scale cargo truck driving simulator, designed for navigating Canada's challenging urban landscapes. Using an immersive VR headset paired with a desk-mounted steering wheel and responsive pedals, drivers experience the real pressure of maneuvering 40-foot vehicles through tight city streets, adverse weather, and complex delivery scenarios. The brilliance? They gain extensive "behind the wheel" experience mastering critical safety skills before ever touching a real commercial vehicle. When mistakes happen—and they will—they're learning opportunities, not insurance claims.

subsections.subheading: Gamified XR Training
subsections.content:
One perennial challenge of any workplace training is engagement. Even when an employee knows the value of the training and wants to do it, we all have other stuff going on outside direct-path, production-hours of work; training can feel like extra work even though it usually isn't. Corporate training, when it adapts by adding gamification, wrestles our attention back to the task at hand in a given lesson.

Points, levels, challenges, trophies and more aren't some workplace gimmick or hack. Training Journal cites a 2024 LMS-industry survey saying 83% of employees feel more engaged when learning is gamified. Learners understand this is a work-related training, but having a little fun is allowed.

subsections.subheading: Blended Learning
subsections.content:
XR technology doesn't solve every workplace training need. Immersive learning is big, but non-immersive, semi-immersive or even hybrid learning can deliver too. That hybrid approach is blended learning.

Blended learning is still an essential element in businesses and organizations, and one example is the foundational learning pillar of theory and practice. These knowledge and attitude (the K and A of KSAs) items work well when paired with ILT. Then, the practical application of extended reality XR can take place in smart glasses, a headset, or a full-on haptics suit. Important note: XR trends are big in 2025, but ILT isn't going anywhere.

If a task involves procedural, spatial, and situational rehearsal–and steady nerves while doing so–blended learning is a great approach.

subsections.subheading: MicroLearning
subsections.content:
Putting on a headset for 90 seconds might not make sense, but microlearning is actually longer than that. Some microlearning experts say it can be up to 15 minutes. (Though the average is five to ten). But XR devices can include a desktop monitor if it has enough CPU power and high definition. More and more, desktop mini-modules of immersive learning through a flat or wraparound monitor can deliver quality corporate training in a snack-sized microlearning module.

The average attention span is going down, even for adults. Just-in-time (JIT) learning and on-demand skills adaptations are not going anywhere. XR industry trends 2025 will see the expansion of XR technology beyond the typical large VR headsets and AR glasses. But even then, five or ten minutes of intense safety training in a headset still leaves an impression on the learner.

subsections.subheading: Haptic Feedback
subsections.content:
Sensory data strongly influences how we perform workplace skills. Did you know the technical definition of skills at the beginning of the L&D world specifically involved the use of movement and fine motor skills, particularly the hands? Even outside of manual labor, almost everyone uses their hands at work in some way. And the journal Advanced Material Technologies wrote about a fingertip haptic device that is 2 millimeters thick and weighs about a of an quarter-ounce (or less than 8 grams). Even wearing one on each finger, this is still at least three times lighter than most consumer immersive gloves that weigh four ounces minimum.

Healthcare is seeing significant developments in the use of haptic gloves. The ultra-precise calibration of increasingly smaller devices for fine-motor skills goes well with the demanding dexterity of those in the medical field. Surgical training is showing a big interest. In the financial field, one report cites over 900 companies worldwide getting involved in haptics devices and research.

subsections.subheading: AR Glasses
subsections.content:
The Ray-Bans Meta partnership, previously a lagging seller, has tripled in the last year. Once a novelty, lightweight digitally-enhanced spectacles of all brands are seeing more and more use in the workplace and corporate training. According to BrandXR, half of the Fortune 100 jumped into an enterprise trial of Apple's Vision Pro. And that was only three months in.

These are the type of glasses that you can walk around in and still effectively navigate your surroundings. Using projections of digital symbols or overlays, they can work for things like navigational arrows for a warehouse worker. With the growing industries offering countless goods for home delivery, freight and warehouse needs are going to go up regardless of extended reality XR trends 2025.

As for soft skills, Google has a set of AR glasses that work pretty well when it comes to communication. A tech writer wrote for The Verge about her trying out Samsung's glasses. The XR device projected text of an English translation across the lenses in real-time as someone spoke to her in Spanish.

subsections.subheading: Hand and Eye Tracking
subsections.content:
Not long ago, VR headsets externally mounted cameras to track human motions. And even then, it was only bigger motions that registered. However, developers are heading in the direction of greater accuracy, and XR trends are following.

Hand and eye tracking are particularly useful for enterprise needs because measuring these movements supplies data. Is the learner actually looking at the machine they're working on? Did they apply the right amount of hand strength to turn the dial? For safety training, did they touch the door first to see if the structure fire had spread to that room they're about to enter? All of these steps and motions can be indexed and ranked.

Moving beyond cameras for hand-tracking was an advancement, but a company called Kopin has created AR glasses that can interpret eye movement and reactions. And it can do so without a camera! It's being explored as a possible aid for surgeons.

sections.heading: AR and VR Training Metrics
sections.content: It's not just hand movements and eye movements that can be measured and indexed. Extended reality trends are showing that businesses are definitely interested in XR. Those companies are starting to ask the question: "this looks promising, but can you prove that it works?" That's where metrics come in.

subsections.subheading: Extended Reality Trends 2025 and Measurable Workplace Improvement Potential
subsections.content: Aviation ground crews can track the amount of time they need to run an inspection on aircraft. Metrics and analytics are the next level of evaluation, where workplace decisions are informed by insights from real user behavior rather than after-the-fact testing alone.
list: Reduced workplace accidents
Tightening up processes, by time and output
Quicker onboarding and time-to-competency

subsections.subheading: Evolution of Headsets
subsections.content: Lighter hardware overall and increased field-of-vision are making immersive learning even more immersive. Better comfort and maneuverability come from decreased size and weight. Being able to detect peripheral objects is also an essential part of any workplace training focused on safety. Improved field of vision helps with that. AR glasses aren't usually called headsets, but they signal the broader shift in XR trends: smaller, lighter, easier. Smart glasses are new, but headsets have been around for a while. The first ones were about the size of a cinderblock (and probably not much lighter). In 2025, smaller and lighter is where XR technology providers are heading.

sections.heading: The Future of Extended Reality Learning
sections.content:
Extended reality continues to erode the necessarily dangerous and/or costly elements in corporate training. As the technology improves, immersive environments will become more immersive. With that immersion, the fidelity of a simulation will mean much more realistic job, skills and corporate training for all users. Users and business leaders want proof and metrics help with that.

Lighter, smaller and more comfortable devices are also major XR trends in 2025 and beyond. Devices become more and more wearable. The feeling of wearing a device at all becomes less and less. We're even seeing some technology, like the hydraulic finger haptics and increasingly precise hand-tracking, that require tiny devices or no device at all.

The future of extended reality learning is that it will extend further into its approximation of reality. With that, we can expect increasingly better results for workplaces that take a serious look at XR adoption for their training.

content.introduction:
Microlearning is learning content, delivered in a small chunks to address a clearly-identified gap in knowledge, skills or attitudes (KSAs). To define microlearning more clearly: it is usually in a portable or easy-access format (handout, mobile doc, Articulate slides, common app).

👉 Corporate microlearning is the granola-bar of training and development: a short and sweet but substantive snack; conveniently packaged, easy to distribute and quickly consumable.

Unforgettable Snacks? The psychologist Hermann Ebbinghaus developed the "forgetting curve," which was a complex series of experiments and equations about memory. While it's a complicated stat, one figure from the Ebbinghaus forgetting curve is that the information starts fading within 20 minutes; even if someone memorizes the content word-for-word. So even if an employee learns a process by heart at the end of an evening skills training, some of it's already gone before they get home!

By giving a learner less to learn, microlearning courses encourage better memory retention. That's one big way that the compact, on-demand, bullseye-specific practice of microlearning modules works. But there are many other effective elements to it. In this article we'll look at these short bursts of focused practice, microlearning videos, and various training insights that keep learners engaged.

sections.heading: Types of Microlearning - by Format and Medium
sections.content:
Short digital content or hardcopy handout: training insights can come from a PDF, an interactive but small flowchart that's accessible by browser, a QRC (quick reference card) and more. Example: the "wrist coach"/playbook a quarterback wears to know the play action. 🏈

Short videos: a quick video can be a standalone job aid for simple viewing, or it can instruct the learner in an interactive task. Example: a three-minute video showing an onboarder at a financial services firm how to set up and log in to their company email. Short videos are among the most effective microlearning examples.

FAQ sites: FAQ sites are the ultimate on-demand examples of microlearning. An example could be a webpage on the company intranet; what were the "A.B.C.'s of customer service again"? That sort of thing.

Short eLearning courses: Brief eLearning courses can be interactive and are an effective way to deliver information-rich content. Example: an Articulate module for compliance training on signing out the keys to a forklift at a warehouse. It might have four frames and a fill-in-the-blank last section.

sections.heading: What Are the Benefits of Microlearning?
sections.content: Saving time is a universal benefit in any workplace, but corporate microlearning has many other advantages besides brevity. The benefits of microlearning include employee engagement, less demand on attention spans, and a default better rate of how to retain information.

subsections.subheading: Enhanced Memory Retention
subsections.content: This happens in two ways. 1) Only one small, discrete item within a knowledge, skill or attitude can be addressed in one module. By simple volume, that makes it easier to remember. 2) five to ten minutes means only the most essential key concepts of the solution can be squeezed in: important problem → exact solution → the end. This is one way microlearning in corporate training can improve memory retention.

subsections.subheading: Employee Engagement
subsections.content: Microlearning sessions are going to be done by the employee, not for the employee. Right there, we see an ownership element. A key principle of adult education is that it relies heavily on internal motivation, and microlearning is basically always on the learner's own schedule or is as needed. When they're internally motivated to get it done, employees are more likely to do it, which will definitely boost engagement. Corporate microlearning is therefore one of the strongest ways to keep learners engaged and increase overall employee engagement.

subsections.subheading: Corporate Microlearning Is Incredibly Flexible
subsections.content: It's flexible for the company designing it; a four-minute video or six different slides are not major time investments. Microlearning strategy is also flexible for the demanding schedules that employees might have. A parent actually can meaningfully read, learn, and internalize a three-page PDF during the half-time of their daughter's evening volleyball game.

subsections.subheading: Scalable
subsections.content: How do you measure ROI in microlearning? One thing we can say for sure is that the initial costs won't be high since it requires fewer resources. The small size also means you can create multiple microlearning modules instead of one big, long course. Regarding the latter, that class size is limited by getting everyone into the same room, but microlearning in corporate training scales more easily.

subsections.subheading: On-Demand
subsections.content: One key attribute used to define microlearning is that it's on-demand. Employees are going to look for it when they need it, making such trainings uniquely relevant. On-demand access to microlearning courses can help employees retain information and apply key points directly on the job.

sections.heading: What Are The Disadvantages Of Microlearning?
sections.content:
Microlearning in corporate training is—not to put too fine a point on it—a "hack." Bigger, more complex topics or highly consequential tasks like OSHA-related safety compliance training—stuff that doesn't fit a shortcut—are usually not suited to corporate microlearning.

Potential fragmentation: It's great for things that can go together as distinct lessons or modules. Think of the classic magazine design rather than a book. A book has progressing chapters but in a magazine, there are quality standalone articles still within a broader idea or topic. You don't have to read all of them to understand just one.

Not suited for complex systems: Does the training gap involve multi-step equipment operations? Does it involve regulatory frameworks or compliance? There's simply too much relevant information to put into microlearning. Even if it was broken into numerous tiny modules, microlearning modules—by design—have little or no overlap. In such cases, in depth training is required.

Not suited for bedrock skills: Think of the instruction manuals that come with a ceiling fan. They won't teach someone how to be an electrician. Likewise, microlearning examples are for tasks or skills within an established body of knowledge or for something universally intuitive. Complex topics that require in depth training are not suitable for this format.

Required training or remedial skills: On-demand and at your own schedule is great. Still, sometimes, training in the workplace needs to happen regardless of buy-in. It's essential to consider how necessary the training is and how motivated your particular learners will be to do it.

sections.heading: 7 Best Practices For Incorporating Microlearning in Corporate Training
sections.content: Thinking of designing your own "granola bar" recipe? It could even be another type of snack, but it needs to be small, easily distributed, quickly consumable and sweet but not too sweet. Examples of microlearning are suddenly a little harder than we thought at first. Don't fret, Roundtable Learning's award-winning workplace skills and strategy team has some training insights and key points.

subsections.subheading: Zero in On One Learning Objective
subsections.content: Microlearning in corporate training is outcome-based. What one (maybe two if they're small) knowledges, skills or attitudes do you genuinely need employees to retain information on and then use to change something?

subsections.subheading: Naturally, Keep it Short
subsections.content: Most sources say we can define microlearning modules as between 5 and 10 minutes (or shorter). For written or spoken content, keep word counts in mind. People silently read at 238 words per minute in English on average, so shoot for 150 words per minute so everyone can keep up. 150 wpm is also a good calculation for spoken content. Short bursts of training keep attention spans from wandering.

subsections.subheading: The Right Format
subsections.content: Design with the task and the audience in mind. Consult at least a few people in the given field about whether your training is best as a PDF handout, microlearning videos, an Articulate mini-module or something else.

subsections.subheading: Make It Super-Easy to Find and Access
subsections.content: Mobile learning is an excellent option for microlearning in corporate training just not if they have to install a dodgy app (if using an app, go for established ones) or use a dodgy browser plug-in. Can someone easily access and begin the lesson within 90 seconds? That is a good starting point.

subsections.subheading: Related Tasks: 👍 Overlapping Tasks: ❌
subsections.content: A key way to define microlearning is that training materials are enclosed in a single, short entity. Modules or training insights can be clumped together within a broader topic, but they cannot stack on each other or overlap. Think of the magazine design.

subsections.subheading: Hard Skills Over Soft Skills (with Some Exceptions)
subsections.content: Tasks or subtasks with a beginning and an end are ideal examples of microlearning. That straightforward nature means soft skills—with some exceptions—are better suited to other modalities. However, something like short customer service processes can work. Plus, there's always room for some L&D ingenuity.

subsections.subheading: Evaluate and Adjust
subsections.content: Include some way to test what the employee learned— such as short quizzes—or evaluate their performance afterward at the given task. Doing both ensures learners engaged with the content and actually retain information.

sections.heading: Could Microlearning Work For Your Employees?
sections.content: Microlearning strategy means identifying essential but shrinkable solutions to employee skills gaps. From there, you could answer: how do you measure ROI in microlearning? If you're mapping your next wave of updates, consider micro-assets as the default. A good microlearning strategy starts small, requires fewer resources, and delivers measurable results to boost engagement and sustain attention spans.

content.conclusion: Microlearning represents a powerful approach to corporate training that delivers focused, accessible learning experiences. By understanding its benefits, limitations, and best practices, organizations can effectively integrate microlearning into their training strategies to improve employee performance and engagement.

sections.heading: 10 Benefits of Microlearning; A Closer Look
sections.content: Now that we understand what microlearning is, let's explore the ten key benefits that make it such a powerful training approach.

subsections.subheading: 1. Boosts Retention
subsections.content: Almost anyone can remember a phone number, a single address, or maybe their license plate, because it doesn't create cognitive overload. By simple volume, if there's less to remember, then there's also less to forget! That much is self-evident. But, there's more. We know review is key to learning and repetition or sufficiently distanced review sessions of something helps us better retain it. And it's much easier to repeat something that's five minutes long and is accessible on your phone. Maybe a learner won't need to repeat it. But if they do, the solve-the-problem-and-move-on nature of microlearning courses insists that no irrelevant things need to be remembered.

subsections.subheading: 2. Strong Engagement
subsections.content:
A key point of adult education is reinforcing why something will benefit the learner in a practical way. This "down payment" by the trainer front loads some motivation. A related point is that–while it sounds elementary–motivation is the shortest distance between a learner and engagement. Microlearning shows evidence of greater engagement and motivation, as cited in the journal Educational Technology Research and Development, which references six published learning experts. The journal concludes the following: "MML [mobile microlearning] can improve learner motivation, engagement, and performance."

Going the mobile learning path is usually a solid option too: we're all pretty engaged with our phones nowadays (regardless of an activity's usefulness.) Why not make it useful?

According to Training Development (TD) Magazine from Sept 2020, Microlearning revs training engagement by 50% and retention by over 20%

subsections.subheading: 3. Enhanced Flexibility
subsections.content: Depending on the size of their family or the generation they're from, employees have only so much disposable time outside of work. But everyone has five or ten minutes. Being available anytime is negotiable, as life outside of one's job becomes a more discussed topic in the workplace, but everyone has five minutes. Additionally, the variety of media and formats available to microlearning modules can be adapted to different learning preferences.

subsections.subheading: 4. Ease of Scalability
subsections.content: Every business wants to reuse things where they can. Multiple people using the same thing at the same time gets even better results and that's possible with microlearning. In contrast to certain traditional training methods, once something is created and mass-produced, the benefits of microlearning-based training start as soon as the PDFs are handed out or the URL is shared.

subsections.subheading: 5. On-demand learning
subsections.content: Providing training microlearning content at the point of need or JIT (just-in-time) means it's meeting a demand. The low-learner-demand threshold of microlearning corporate training programs means "on your own schedule"; another term for on demand.

subsections.subheading: 6. Personalized Learning
subsections.content: By nature of its narrow focus, microlearning modules can address the individual learner's specific skills gap or at least a smaller group's skills gap within a workplace. The personalized approach works best when a variety of microlearning content (also called a learning library) is available to employees. From this, they can select or be assigned only the things that they need or want to take; what's relevant to them and their workplace needs, personally. Think about it, there's a reason why "targeted" ads are so popular and why countless websites have cookies and trackers; personalization works.

subsections.subheading: 7. Skill Gap Closing & Problem Solving
subsections.content: Information is constantly growing. 402.74 million terabytes of data are produced every day. And as we learn more, we find more ways to improve the work we do. Many of these new improvements will require new skills or sub-skills. Also, as the growth of information accelerates, we learn about more potential ways to solve problems. At this scale, time-consuming traditional learning methods will be reserved for major needs. Frequent but manageable problems or skills gap needs are where a compact learning process like microlearning can definitely fill in.

subsections.subheading: 8. Learning Culture
subsections.content: When used right, microlearning delivers major dividends for growing a learning culture in the workplace. As DPE's Chief People Officer noted in HR Grapevine UK, the generally younger workforce employed by DPE (Domino's Pizza Enterprises) was very smartphone-literate. The perfect alignment of microlearning modules with mobile learning just made sense. And the app they created was a smash hit. There were nine layers of mini-lessons, from onboarding new hires up to developing new franchisee relationships.

subsections.subheading: 9. Cost-Effectiveness
subsections.content:
Smaller-sized micronlearning content, just by simple math, has lower development costs. A two-page PDF is fewer labor hours to pay a writer for than drafting a full-length manual. A seven-slide Articulate 360 module takes less time to develop than a full-on learning path.

But here's a clear-cut example. Two hospital systems on the west coast merged in the 2010s, creating a workforce that numbered over 100,000 people. The plodding nature of annual training was starting to wear on hospital workers. The hospital system worked to create on-demand microlearning modules using mobile learning and saved seven figures per year.

"With the findings [data on a microlearning initiative] in hand, we were able to articulate a return on investment of $4 million in productivity savings each year for each enterprise-wide course." – Darci Hall, former Chief Learning Officer, writing in TD Magazine about microlearning initiatives at Providence health systems

subsections.subheading: 10. Perfect for Any Generation
subsections.content:
Nearly all people still in the workforce have realized that the learning process no longer ends at college or vocational school graduation, or completing an apprenticeship. Workplace learning is here to stay. But different generations learn differently in general–at least when it comes to workplace KSAs.

Despite those differences, microlearning can fit most any generation of workers with corporate training needs.
list: Millennials and Gen Z are, needless to say, very comfortable with digital and mobile learning; interactive features like quizzes or gamification can be an added bonus.
Gen X (and "Xennials") can adapt to most anything. Gen X is also the most likely to have above-average time demands of a growing family. On-demand learning works for that.
subsections.additionalContent: Boomers like clear feedback, and that's easy when there's not a lot to evaluate. Having little to evaluate is the nature of microlearning modules. The get-to-the-point, simplified structure of information that is required for microlearning content is also something they appreciate.

sections.content:
The modern workplace–for all employees–now includes a constant learning process, whether that's online training or otherwise. And that's true regardless of the industry.

On that list, these criteria are typed in size 72 font, underlined and bold: reduce errors and boost productivity. Volume and safe operations are vital. In a warehouse environment, volume is the foundation, but safe operations is the bedrock. And there are actually some soft skills, including how to help everyone communicate clear expectations.

subsections.subheading: Safety Is Critical. Full Stop
subsections.content:
Simply put–organizations with warehouses aren't casual about safety procedures and safety training. They don't want to be, and they can't afford to be. If you're reading this and you work in warehouse operations, you already know this.

Yet, there's a lot that goes into those protocols. If you want an idea about how complex it gets, look at a chart diagramming the ideas behind this keystone of safety warehouse operations, as identified by the 5th Logistics International Conference. Indeed, it's a tad complex.

But if we take away nothing else from the conference diagram, we can safely say pairing smooth operations with heavy machinery and logistics coordination is a complicated process. content.introduction:
While Virtual Reality (VR) and Augmented Reality (AR) aren't the same, AR vs VR have a lot in common. They have the ability to immerse learners in a digital experience that mirrors the real world. 

As you can imagine, this type of comprehensive reflection of reality can be used for learning and not just entertainment. Immersive learning boosts learner engagement, and different industries use AR and VR to create a simulated environment for their employees. Simulation training or skill training in a virtual world is a useful and lower-risk modality for countless tasks and training scenarios in today's workplace.

In this article, we'll explain the main differences between AR and VR. But we'll focus on niching down to your needs specifically. We'll help you determine whether AR or VR is better suited for your given real-world workplace training program.

⚙️⚙️⚙️AR vs VR. Let's Drill-Down and Get Technical: 

VR and AR both create perceptions using digital, electrical or motion-based stimuli. They both generate or display sights, sounds and sensations within virtual environments.⚙️⚙️⚙️

sections.heading: What Is VR?
sections.content: In practice, it generally applies to the most immersive digital experiences available. Using a headset and handheld controllers, learners can look around, interact with virtual objects, and move through a 3D space as if they were really there.

subsections.subheading: The Finer Distinctions of AR vs VR
subsections.content:
VR experiences are designed to fully immerse the learner, often using handheld controllers or motion-based inputs to interact with the environment. The goal is to replicate real-world tasks as closely as possible through VR contents like digital visuals, motion tracking, and audio—creating a powerful sense of presence.

In most VR training, the focus remains on digitized (and sometimes recorded video) content, paired with audio to create a rich, interactive learning environment.

⚙️⚙️⚙️AR vs VR. Let's Drill-Down and Get Technical:

VR experiences are designed to fully immerse the learner, sometimes using handheld controllers or motion-based inputs to interact with the environment. The goal is to replicate real-world tasks as closely as possible through VR contents like digital visuals, motion tracking, and audio—creating a powerful sense of presence. In short, VR contents are focused on creating as much of the experience as possible. Most VR training has the focus on digitized (and sometimes recorded video) content, paired with audio to create a rich, interactive learning environment.⚙️⚙️⚙️

VR comes in levels, too; ranging from non-immersive to semi-immersive and fully immersive.

subsections.subheading: Examples of the Three Levels of VR
subsections.content:
Non-immersive involves interacting with a virtual environment through a standard screen like a high-resolution 3D video game on a large monitor using a keyboard, mouse, or controller. The user is aware of and grounded in the real world. 

→ Example: Playing a 3D simulation game on a desktop.

Semi-immersive would be a basic headset without full sensory input or tracking, like sound and playspace. The immersive virtual space is, figuratively, waist-deep, and the real world is still very present.

→ Example: A headset-based training simulation without motion tracking or 3D audio.

Fully immersive is a fully enclosed experience. They typically involve a high-end headset with motion tracking, hand controllers, and 3D audio. Users feel completely engaged in the virtual world, with minimal awareness of their physical surroundings.

→ Example: A VR training simulation with headset, hand tracking, and spatial audio that reacts to learner input.

sections.heading: What Is AR?
sections.content:
Augmented Reality (AR) enhances the real world by overlaying digital content like text, images, or 3D objects, onto a user's physical environment through a smartphone, tablet, or AR-enabled headset.

With AR, learners can interact with virtual instructions layered on real-world equipment, preview digital objects within the physical world, or visualize complex systems in motion. A common example is IKEA's app, which allows users to place and view digital models of furniture in their home using their phone's camera to see if it fits in their space.

AR content can include shapes, annotations, animations, or even full 3D models, helping users better understand real-world tasks through real-time guidance and visualization.

Devices that support AR include smartphones, tablets, and AR headsets like Microsoft HoloLens, Magic Leap or Snapchat Spectacles. While some wearable tech (like Ray-Ban Stories or Echo Frames) includes cameras and voice assistants, they don't yet offer true AR functionality.

⚙️⚙️⚙️AR vs VR. Let's Drill-Down and Get Technical:

AR programs involve a constellation of digital entities seen through a portal. That portal could be a smartphone, a tablet or another device. Those entities can be shapes, letters (or characters, depending on the language), linear outlines, annotations or a number of digitally-produced visual elements. The digital entities can overlay, outline or enhance what the person sees. AR can also create or broadcast into place whole objects over a blank space.⚙️⚙️⚙️

AR doesn't have distinct levels or types, but it has four capabilities. (Various experts in the field say it's three, others say five different types or capabilities). Some of the functions overlap (and overlapping is one type of AR, just to make things even more confusing), but these are the three primary ways it works: 1) marker-based, 1a) non-marker-based, 2) projection and 3) overlap.

subsections.subheading: Examples of AR's in AR vs VR Main Capabilities/Types
list: Marker-based AR – Uses a visual trigger (like a QR code or image) to launch AR content.
Markerless AR – Uses GPS, accelerometers, or other sensors to place AR content without a visual marker.
Projection-based AR – Projects light or images onto physical surfaces to simulate interaction.
Superimposition-based AR – Replaces part of the real-world view with an enhanced version (e.g., highlighting parts of a machine for repair).

sections.heading: What VR Training Is and the Best Times to Use It
sections.content:
While they're known for their applications in entertainment, both VR training and AR's earliest uses were for the workplace. VR was used as a simulated environment of flight, and AR was an enhanced way to look at plane blueprints. While being quality mediums for entertainment, they actually have a lot of usefulness in the workplace and are likely a great asset for your specific business model.

"AR's basic functionality consists of creating links, direct or triggered by user interaction with the device, between the real world and the information generated by a device or electronic information." 

An Overview of Augmented Reality – Arena, F; Collatta, M; Giovanni, P; Termine, F | Computers (journal)

In VR, the level of immersion depends on the degrees of freedom available in the device and content. A VR headset will usually have content with a virtual six degrees of freedom (6DoF or 'six doff') or the ability to simulate motion up, down, left, right, forward and backward.

→ For more on the importance of 3DoF and 6DoF, check out our article 3DoF vs. 6DoF Virtual Reality: Which Is Better? – Roundtable Learning

subsections.subheading: VR-Specific Immersive Learning and Training Scenarios; Quality Use Cases in AR vs VR
subsections.content:
Real world scenarios of Response-based Safety. VR training is a more thoroughly immersive technology than AR, as it removes all distractions from the real world allowing learners to focus, react, and make decisions just as they would in a high-stakes situation, minus the actual danger. 

There are numerous situations such as fire drills, disaster evacuation, active shooter or chemical spill events where VR is especially effective. Hazardous environments where an emergency response with split-second real time feedback is necessary are among the best situations for full-on, get-in-and-go VR.

Critical Soft Skills Through VR Role-Play. Real-world scenarios meas people need to interact with others. For high-risk, interpersonal roles like law enforcement or triage nurses, success often comes down to communication, de-escalation, and decision-making under stress. 

VR makes it possible to safely rehearse these interactions through immersive role-play scenarios. Whether it's navigating a tense conversation or responding to an armed individual, learners can follow proven communication strategies in a realistic simulation. 

The simulation can produce these real world scenarios as digital information so as to create an immersive experience. Step-by-step tactics and branching scenarios help reinforce the right behaviors, so employees are prepared to handle interpersonal challenges with confidence and care. In these cases, step-by-step, flowchart-style de-escalation tactics and strategic communication can actually be rehearsed. 

Simulated Driving in Virtual Reality. DHL, UPS and CN have utilized modified VR to train parcel delivery truck drivers. The complete and total hands on experience with roads, other vehicles, and the real life potential distractions present a quality training program. These challenges and obstacles, when practiced in their unavoidable everyday environments, set the drivers up for safer and faster deliveries.

subsections.subheading: AR vs VR and When an AR Experience Would Be Better than VR
subsections.content:
There are workplace scenarios that require both gross motor skills (like lifting or reaching) and fine motor skills (like gripping or manipulating small parts). For this, AR is a better application.

VR's external cameras or laser-activated tracking works for larger body movement like arms, legs and even hands. But it often falls short when it comes to capturing the tiny, precise motions needed for tasks that involve extremely fine articulations of individual fingers or actions that require strong grips and movements.

That's where AR's attention to detail stands out for better learning experiences for immersive training. AR allows learners to interact directly with real-world tools and equipment like working on engines, control panels or any device requiring acute depth perception In these cases AR will produce better learning experiences for immersive training.

sections.heading: What AR Training Is and the Best Times to Use It
sections.content:
AR training needs extend the realistic dimensions of learning. They do so by augmenting the real world learning environment, rather than blunting it. In fact, AR training solutions can actually sharpen it.

As noted, the main difference between AR and VR fundamentally lies in their approach to reality. VR is almost always full immersion; isolating the user within a completely digital environment with little or no interaction with the physical world. AR, however, adds to the real world by overlaying digital information or "simulated visual items" onto it. It interacts with the real world while adding to it, allowing learners to maintain their awareness and interact with their physical surroundings while receiving digital guidance or information.

subsections.subheading: Fixing, Replacing, Manufacturing and Maintenance Are Big AR Applications
Fixing, Replacing and Maintenance
subsections.content:
When you need to do two things at once while learning, AR is a great tool. A simulation based training can have someone view an engine through AR spectacles. By designing the content and the sensors to actuate at the right time, the spectacles can highlight a given component that needs to be replaced, like an AC compressor. A hovering outline of that engine part with highlight itself on the lens, and the learner then knows where to find it.

A digital 3D model is overlaid through object recognition, giving learners an interactive reference for taking components apart and putting them back together. This method allows them to focus on individual tasks in a highly immersive, hands-on manner. A learner can focus on one thing at a time.

subsections.subheading: Feeling vs. Seeing
subsections.content:
If individual finger movements need to be tracked, both VR and AR have features that accommodate this. However, if the learning experience requires that learners need direct physical interation, such as with hand or power tools, AR is better suited.

Tactile feedback is essential in scenarios where sight and motion alone doesn't provide enough context. Sometimes, there is a need to feel the physical pressure of a learning experience. The ability to physically engage with real-world equipment adds a layer of realism that strengthens understanding and improves performance. Still both modalities in the AR vs VR side have the capacity. It's the level that varies.  

In fields like osteopathic medicine, for example, learners must perform procedures with specially-crafted instruments. These instruments measure distance and pressure or other metrics down to tenths of an inch, because success depends on precise, hands-on dexterity. But medical simulation training is just one instance.

subsections.subheading: AR Helps with Tasks Requiring High-Engagement and Large-Scale, Personal Navigation
subsections.content:
AR helps a person see and feel. And not just on their hands. 

In the workplace, AR helps learners not only see and feel but also move and do.

The average warehouse or distribution center is enormous. These structures are built for size, safety and little else. Knowing where to go and how to get there is essential if the learning objectives include finding a single product in a building that might house 15,000 different items on its many shelves.

Finding a device in an enormous warehouse can be done by using AR spectacles–which still allow for a largely unobstructed view of one's surroundings–the learner has numerous guideposts and instructions on where to find the object. Arrows on the floor can point in the direction to walk. Blinking shapes can highlight a location on a shelf. Audio narration can provide even more information.

sections.heading: Which Is Best for You
sections.content: AR vs VR? Both have practical training applications—but their strengths differ based on what your workforce needs to see, feel, interact with, or practice.
list:
Choose VR when your training goals involve:
  - Full immersion and uninterrupted attention
  - High-risk response scenarios
  - Rehearsals of complex interpersonal interactions
  - Vehicle operation or full-environment simulations

Choose AR when your tasks require:
  - Working directly with real-world equipment
  - Visual overlays for repairs, replacements, or manufacturing
  - Step-by-step physical engagement, especially with fine motor skills
  - Navigating large spaces like warehouses or production floors with real-time guidance
  - On the job training assistance
sections.additionalContent: While both technologies enhance training effectiveness, the decision depends less on which is 'better' and more on which matches the real-world job functions you're simulating. Start by assessing your environment, your tools, and your learners' tactile needs. Then select the modality that best supports how people will actually work—not just how they'll train.

sections.heading: Key Takeaways in AR vs VR
sections.content: Explain VR – VR delivers immersive learning by digitally recreating environments and simulating physical sensations through specialized equipment.
list: VR uses visual, auditory, and motion-based stimuli to immerse learners in a digitally generated environment, supporting training in realistic settings.
Headsets and optional accessories like controllers or haptic wearables create a deep sense of immersion by simulating touch and motion.
Levels of VR range from non-immersive (e.g., desktop video) to fully immersive experiences with real-time movement tracking and 3D content.
VR training is ideal for scenarios requiring full focus and reduced distraction from the surrounding physical world.

subsections.subheading: Explain AR – AR adds simulated elements to the physical world by layering digital visuals through devices like phones or smart glasses.
list: AR allows digital overlays—such as graphics, annotations, or 3D objects—to appear in the real world through cameras and sensors.
It operates through mobile screens or wearable glasses, offering a lightweight and real-time interface with physical environments.
There are several AR modes, including marker-based, projection mapping, and graphic overlap, each producing different levels of interactivity.
AR training supports realism by enhancing the physical world rather than replacing it, which is helpful in context-sensitive environments.

subsections.subheading: What VR Training Is and When to Use It – VR is best used for high-stakes training situations that require realism without actual risk.
list: VR is particularly useful in emergency response scenarios where trainees need to rehearse their actions under pressure without real-world danger.
Law enforcement, medical, and interpersonal crisis simulations benefit from VR's ability to model escalated social dynamics and decision points.
Vehicle training programs have leveraged VR to expose drivers to real-world navigation challenges in controlled, repeatable formats.
VR should be used when training demands total focus, spatial immersion, and the ability to simulate danger or complexity safely.

subsections.subheading: What AR Training Is and When to Use It – AR is ideal when real-time interaction with physical tools, locations, or fine motor skills is required.
list: AR allows learners to augment real environments while handeling real equipment and receiving visual guidance through overlays or animated cues.
It helps workers follow procedural steps in real time, such as assembly, diagnostics, or maintenance tasks that require precise hand movements.
AR training solutions maintain full visibility of the environment, making them well-suited for depth-sensitive or large-scale navigation tasks.
AR enhances tactile learning by combining visual and sensory feedback with real-world engagement.

subsections.subheading: Which Is Best for You – The choice between VR and AR depends on the sensory, spatial, and technical needs of the job being trained.
list: Use VR when full immersion, environmental control, or emergency simulations are necessary to reach your learning goals.
Choose AR for tasks involving physical objects, step-based workflows, or large physical spaces requiring guided navigation.
Training success depends on matching the delivery method with the actual work environment—not simply on the technology itself.
Analyze your tools, surroundings, and skill requirements before selecting the most effective modality.
